hints.content:
In DNS spoofing, a cyber criminal sends an incorrect IP addres to a domain resolver service, and that service then caches the incorrect domain ↔ IP mapping.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: DNS spoofing diagram: A server labeled "ISP Domain Resolver" is on the left, and another server labeled "Fake Name Server" is on the right. An arrow goes from the ISP Domain Resolver to the Fake Name Server that says "www.wikipedia.org = ?", a arrow goes from the Fake Name Server to the ISP Domain Resolver with an IP address in it.

hints.content:
When a computer asks that domain resolver for the corresponding IP to a domain, it receives the incorrect IP.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: DNS spoofing diagram: A laptop is on the left and a server labeled "ISP Domain Resolver" is on the right. An arrow goes from the laptop to the server that says "www.wikipedia.org = ?", a arrow goes from the server to the laptop with an IP address in it. The laptop displays a website with a red skull & bones on it.

hints.content:
The incorrect IP often leads to a website owned by the cyber criminal. Sometimes that website is a simple page, like "you've been hacked!". 

In this case, the website looks somewhat like the original site, but contains different content. The cyber criminals are likely hoping to get the users to click the buttons and enter private banking account details.  That's what makes DNS spoofing so dangerous.

Note that the cyber criminals *do not* necessarily have access to the original servers or databases. That would be a different type of attack.

Thus, this is a good explanation of this DNS spoofing attack:

Cybercriminals hacked into a DNS server and redirected the mapping for the "banksrus.com" domain name to an IP address that they control.

question.content:
Reina navigates to her bank's website:

![Screenshot of banking website. Address bar says "banksrus.com". Webpage has a logo, header, and two buttons that say "Make deposit" and "Transfer money"](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/443eeba8eba1f1b187dc8bc94eacf77d63458584.png)

She notices it looks different from usual - strange fonts and layout, plus it doesn't show how much money is in her banking accounts.

Reina checks Twitter and sees reports of a DNS spoofing attack on the banking site:

![Screenshot of tweet from user account @banks_r_us, which says "We detected a DNS spoofing attack on our banking site. Do not log into banksrus.com today!"](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/37908282be6a3d1e5dc100949488db6a516ce7fe.png)

**What is a good explanation of this DNS spoofing attack?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Cyber criminals hacked into a DNS server and redirected the mapping for the "banksrus.com" domain name to an IP address that they control.

choices.clue: In DNS spoofing, the cyber criminal does not have access to the original servers.
choices.content: Cyber criminals hacked into the BanksRUs servers and replaced the website code with their own website code.

choices.clue: In DNS spoofing, the cyber criminal does not have access to the original servers or databases.
choices.content: Cyber criminals hacked into the BanksRUs databases and replaced all user's banking account details with new details.

choices.clue: In DNS spoofing, the cyber criminal does not have direct access to a user's computer.
choices.content: Cyber criminals took control of Reina's laptop and are directing the browser to load different files.
